metadata.sermon_start_end: An Old Testament teacher cannot get any closer to the New Testament than Malachi 4:5–6. They are the last two verses of the Old Testament in the Christian Bible, and they nuzzle close up against Matthew and the story of Jesus. [...] Pause in the frenzy to make space for the absent one, about to become present, to intrude to make all things new. No wonder they confused the host of this meal with Elijah.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon explicitly moves away from the assigned pericope (Malachi 3) to focus on a 'biblical character' (Elijah). According to Dekker, a speech about a character is not a sermon. It fails to identify what is in this specific text that is nowhere else; instead, it harmonizes the text with the whole Bible.
quotes: They are not quite the lectionary assigned for the day... So I cheated a little
That means that you cannot understand what time it is, unless you know about Elijah, a key character in the Old Testament
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus strictly on the assigned pericope of Malachi 3:1-4. Avoid 'cheating' to find a more comfortable theme. Identify the unique theological 'point' of the Malachi text itself rather than using it as a springboard for an Elijah-biography.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher provides historical context (800 BCE vs 400 years later), but it remains at the level of storytelling rather than rigorous exposition of the Hebrew text or the specific theological crisis of the post-exilic community in Malachi.
quotes: He appeared in an ancient time, not unlike our own, when the public scene was falling apart
That was in 800 BCE. They kept thinking about him so long, so vividly, that by the time of Malachi...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific linguistic and theological nuances of Malachi’s prophecy. Move beyond general historical 'background material' to the specific 'Why' of the text's original address.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (consumerism, greed, economic scarcity), which aligns with Dekker’s requirement for humanities/sociological awareness. However, it leans toward general truths about 'hope' rather than the specific demand of the text.
quotes: He confronted phoney religion... what we would now call the religion of 'consumerism.'
too much traffic, too much family strife, too much tradition, too much expense
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the application more directly to the 'misery' of the hearer as defined by the text's judgment, rather than just listing modern annoyances or general social ills.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat linear 'then and now' structure. Sections I and II are largely historical/biblical review, while IV moves to application. It lacks the 'simultaneous' movement Dekker demands where the hearer is 'expounded' along with the text.
quotes: Well, that’s a lot of background—but you need to know it.
They kept pondering the ancient Elijah... And if we catalogue what he did...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'background first, application later' model. Let the contemporary reality be the lens through which the text is read from the first paragraph.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories are present: misery (despair, greed), redemption (the coming of the Lord/Elijah), and gratitude (the meal/celebration). However, the 'misery' is somewhat externalized as 'the world' rather than the hearer's own misery before God.
quotes: the world is sick to death.
turn us from despair and anger and brutality and greed and fear.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. Instead of 'the world' being sick, address how the hearer is specifically 'lost' in time or eternity as per the Malachi text's warning of a 'curse'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the 'curse' and the 'edge,' but quickly pivots to a hopeful 'newness.' The seriousness of being 'lost' or the 'two ways' is softened by an emphasis on the 'best hopes.'
quotes: so that I will not come and strike the land with a curse.
But we are not hopeless. We are at the break of God’s future.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Do not rush to the 'hope' without lingering on the 'curse' mentioned in Malachi 4:6. The 'two ways' must be presented as a real, high-stakes choice for the hearer.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher effectively links Elijah’s 'absence' to Christ’s 'presence' and the hope of his return. The doctrine of grace is central to the conclusion.
quotes: Until he comes in power and in grace...
No wonder they confused the host of this meal with Elijah.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'better Elijah' (a theme), but the specific fulfillment of the unique promise found in the Malachi text.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The estimated duration is approximately 12-13 minutes. This fails Dekker’s absolute minimum of 20 minutes. The 'breadth' required for 'depth' is missing; the sermon is too brief to properly expound and apply.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and application to reach at least 20 minutes. Use the extra time to move from general observations to the 'specific' and 'concrete' depth Dekker requires.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily on formal grounds: it is significantly too short (<20 minutes) and prioritizes a biblical character (Elijah) over the specific exposition of a single pericope. While it shows a strong grasp of the zeitgeist and maintains a Christological focus, it lacks the exegetical depth and the 'two ways' urgency demanded by Dekker's theses.
strengths: Strong contemporary relevance regarding consumerism and social greed.
Clear Christological telos that connects the Old Testament figure to the Gospel.
Adequate use of the 'three parts' (misery, redemption, gratitude) as a background framework.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 12 minutes) prevents necessary depth.
Thematic approach (Elijah) rather than pericope-driven exposition.
Softening of the 'two ways'; the threat of the 'curse' is mentioned but not utilized to confront the hearer's will.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This text functions more as a thematic meditation or a 'speech about the gospel' than a sermon in Dekker's strict sense. To become a sermon, it must commit to the specific text of Malachi, confront the hearer with the possibility of being lost, and double its length to achieve the required theological breadth.
